facts.subject: pam
facts.value: I experienced a little of both. I was born in Midland, Texas, and we lived in Annie's house—though I can't recall the street name, I think it was 801 East Texas. We then moved to Denver with Aunt Lil. My mama moved to Denver, and we stayed with Aunt Lil for a while before returning to Midland, where I started kindergarten. We also stayed with Mama Liddy in Malone, Texas, for a time because Big Mama watched Aunt Lil's two boys while she worked. Annie, Mama Liddy, and Aunt Lil were all Big Mama Mamie Sorrell's children. After returning to Midland, I went to kindergarten, then first and second grade there, as well as preschool. In third grade, we moved to California with Aunt Lil, and I stayed there for third and fourth grade. Big Mama came back to Midland when I was in fifth grade, and after finishing that year, I decided to stay with my mama, Esther Pearl, in Denver for sixth grade. I didn't like it because the lifestyle there wasn't what I was used to. Just before graduation, I called Big Mama to come get me. She did, and we went back to Los Angeles, where I completed seventh and eighth grade and stayed until I became pregnant with Jade.

facts.value: There was probably a lot because we didn't share our private life with anyone. Early in our marriage, life was good. When we first got together, Ricky worked for Bethlehem Steel, and I stayed home at first, then got a job at the Red Cross. We were both working and doing well. The first five years had some ups and downs — his mom made him feel stuck, so he left once for my birthday and went to Oakland. My friend's boyfriend answered my phone while Ricky was away, and Ricky thought someone was trying to get close to me. He came back immediately, and we've been together ever since. For a long time, his mom and I didn't get along — not until after Big Mama passed. Something changed in her after that. She didn't like that I chose my kids over drugs, but I stood my ground. My kids were always more important to me than that lifestyle.

facts.value: When you were first born, you were very sickly. We didn't know if the Lord would let us keep you. But when you turned eight months old, you just blossomed. You had a charm about you that made people love you. One of my girlfriends, who didn't work, would watch you while I was at work. She once brought you up to my job and told me not to say anything — she wanted people to think you were hers — but the second you saw me, you yelled, "Mommy!"

facts.value: I met Ricky when I stayed on 65th in Vermont. His sister Linda stayed in the apartment next to Big Mama (it used to be in Lee's apartment). I met him through her and saw her brothers — Clint, Charles, and then Ricky. Charles had tried to talk to me, but I didn't want to because he drank too much. I didn't like Clint because he had a bad attitude. I said, "If I talk to any of your brothers, it would be Ricky." Linda told Ricky, and Ricky took me and Jade to the drive-in because he thought I had more kids. He had been told, "She's got all them kids," but Linda corrected him — "None of them are hers, she just braids their hair. She only has one — the little boy that's always up here with me." facts.subject: pam
facts.value: Living with Big Mama, I remember being surrounded by all my aunts—Aunt Helen, Aunt Lillie, Raina, Annie—and Big Mama's son, Ernest, whom they called Big Brother. I didn't like him because he was a bully who would pull my hair hard. I also recall seeing my cousins with their parents and feeling the absence of my own. Big Mama told me my mama had given me to a woman in a hotel, and Big Mama went and got me back while I was still an infant. I called Big Mama "Mama," and she explained she was my grandmother, but she was raising me. Before moving to California, she would walk me to school, which was just a couple of blocks from Annie's house. When we came to LA, I grew close to Spooky like a brother, but I always felt I didn't truly fit in with my aunts' children. That made me determined that when I had kids, they would always know their mother and father.
facts.original_q: What are some of your earliest childhood memories, good and/or bad?

facts.subject: pam
facts.value: My mother's name was Esther Pearl Sorrows, and my father's name was Hugo Henderson. I never met my father in person, though I spoke to him once on the phone when I was around seven or eight. He said he was coming to see me, but he never arrived—he was said to be sick. He once sent me a porcelain doll that I cherished until a little girl Big Mama cared for broke it. When I was eight, Aunt Lil said she would take me to meet him in Bakersfield, but he died before we could go. I never knew my siblings on his side, though I was told I was the youngest on his side and the oldest on my mother's. My mother was in her early twenties when she had me, and my father was in his fifties. I had one sister from his side, Sandra, who visited me once when I was young. On my mother's side, my siblings were Richard Jr. (RB), Gretchen (a twin whose sister died at birth), Larry, and Lanetta. I was closest to Richard during the year I lived with them in Denver. RV passed away from epilepsy, and Gretchen has also passed. My mother had six children total—three boys and three girls—and four of us are still living today.
facts.original_q: Can you tell me your biological mother and father's name?

facts.value: None that I can think of right now. I just went to school, stayed out of trouble, and didn't do drugs. Spooky, Tony, and their friends smoked weed, and a few tried pills like Red Devils. Seeing how they acted made me say, "If it does that to them, it'll do that to me—I'm not taking that mess." I didn't start smoking weed until I got with your dad, and that's only because he said I didn't do anything. I never drank. I smoked for a little while, but we both quit.

facts.subject: pam
facts.value: Yes—our German Shepherd named Bell. We loved her, and she loved us. Later, Aunt Lil got Pierre, a little poodle. He was Aunt Lil's dog and had a habit of pretending to be hurt so people would fuss over him. Sometimes he'd limp, and then we'd catch him walking just fine. We used to say, "Look, Mama—he's not limping now!"

facts.subject: pam
facts.value: I don't know, Ty—I didn't have a bad childhood. Big Mama made sure I was taken care of. If she thought something was dangerous, she didn't allow me near it. I had cousins she kept me away from, like David Lee—she'd say, "If you see him, you come on back in this house," and I couldn't understand because he was married to my aunt. My grandmother raised me well, and I'm grateful. Only God knows what would've happened if I'd stayed with my mama—my brother went through a lot with her, things I was spared from.

facts.subject: pam
facts.value: Babysitting. I loved kids, so I would babysit the kids on the block because Tony didn't like kids. She said, "You babysit," so I would babysit. I can remember babysitting because I wanted to give Big Mama something special for Mother's Day. She would talk about how hot the back house would be, and I wanted to get her a fan. So I babysat the boys first — they used to live right next door where we stayed on Fifth Avenue. Then the next year they moved, and I started babysitting the ones next door to her. She had two or three girls, and I babysat them. Later, when Deborah had her baby, I was the only one on the block that would do anything with her, because back then people judged you if you had a kid young. But I didn't have a problem with it. I always had kids around me — if kids were involved, I was there.
